Joints

Classes

  • class pJoint
    Abstract base class for the different types of joints. More...
  • class pJointPrismatic
    A prismatic joint permits relative translational movement between two bodies along an axis, but no relative rotational movement. More...
  • class pJointCylindrical
    Cylindrical Joints permit relative translational movement between two bodies along an axis, and also relative rotation along the axis. More...
  • class pJointPointInPlane
    A point in plane joint constrains a point on one actor to only move inside a plane attached to another actor. The point attached to the plane is defined by the anchor point. The joint's axis specifies the plane normal. More...
  • class pJointPointOnLine
    A point on line joint constrains a point on one actor to only move along a line attached to another actor. The point attached to the line is the anchor point for the joint. The line through this point is specified by its direction (axis) vector. More...
  • class pJointRevolute
    A joint which behaves in a similar way to a hinge or axle. More...
  • class pJointPulley
    A pulley joint simulates a rope between two objects passing over 2 pulleys. More...
  • class pJointD6
    A D6 joint is a general constraint between two actors. More...
  • class pJointDistance
    A distance joint maintains a certain distance between two points on two bodies. More...
  • class pJointBall
    A sphere joint constrains two points on two bodies to coincide. More...
  • class pMotor
    Describes a joint motor. Some joints can be motorized, this allows them to apply a force to cause attached actors to move. Joints which can be motorized: pJointPulley pJointRevolute is used for a similar purpose with pJointD6. More...
  • class pJointLimit
    Describes a joint limit. pJointLimit is registered as custom structure pJLimit and can be accessed or modified through parameter operations.
    . More...
  • class pJD6SoftLimit
    Describes a joint soft limit for D6 usage. pJD6SoftLimit is registered as custom structure pJD6SLimit and can be accessed or modified through parameter operations.
    . More...
  • class pJD6Drive
    Class used to describe drive properties for a pJointD6. More...

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum JType

Identifies each type of joint. This enum is registered as a custom enumeration for the schematic interface as pJointType.

Enumerator:
JT_Any 

None

JT_Prismatic 

Permits a single translational degree of freedom. See pJointPrismatic.

JT_Revolute 

Also known as a hinge joint, permits one rotational degree of freedom. See pJointRevolute.

JT_Cylindrical 

Formerly known as a sliding joint, permits one translational and one rotational degree of freedom. See pJointCylindrical.

JT_Spherical 

Also known as a ball or ball and socket joint. See pJointBall.

JT_PointOnLine 

A point on one actor is constrained to stay on a line on another.

JT_PointInPlane 

A point on one actor is constrained to stay on a plane on another.

JT_Distance 

A point on one actor maintains a certain distance range to another point on another actor. See pJointDistance.

JT_Pulley 

A pulley joint. See pJointPulley.

JT_Fixed 

A "fixed" connection. See pJointFixed.

JT_D6 

A 6 degree of freedom joint. See pJointD6.

enum ProjectionMode

Joint projection is a method for correcting large joint errors. Joint errors occur when a joint's constraint is violated - imagine the ball being pulled out of the socket in a spherical joint. Under normal circumstances, joint errors are small yet unavoidable due to the imprecise nature of floating point math and numerical integrators. The SDK applies minimal correcting forces to the simulation to try and reduce joint errors over time. However, if a joint error becomes very large, more drastic measures are necessary, such as joint projection. The SDK can, in some situations, project (or change) the position of objects directly to fix the joint error. But when projecting the joint it is not desirable to completely remove the joint error because the correcting forces, which also affect velocity, would become zero.

Enumerator:
PM_None 

Disables projection.

PM_MinPointDist 

Performs both linear and angular projection.

PM_MinLinearDist 

Only projects linear distances, for improved performance.
